documents.title: why some firms are still using models to sell cars
text: sex sells .
it 's an old mantra , but one which the car industry has been wedded to for many years .
since the 1960s and 70s , it has been common at the major motor shows to see models next to the latest shiny machinery .
here in geneva this year , there are perhaps fewer models on the stands than there have been in the past - but they are still very visible .
so in the 21st century , in the age of # metoo , what are we to make of such attitudes ?
read more
author: Theo Leggett
BBC Business News Reporter

documents.title: wall street gains as trump imposes tariffs
text: wall street had been on edge ahead of donald trump 's announcement of controversial orders imposing heavy tariffs on steel and aluminium .
however , the main stock indexes ended the day in positive territory .
the dow jones closed 93.85 points or 0.38 % higher at 24,895.21 , while the s & p 500 rose 12.17 points or 0.45 % to 2,738.97 .
the tech-heavy nasdaq gained 0.42 % or 31.3 points to 7,427.95 .

documents.title: international women 's day : 'millions ' join spain strike
text: women workers in spain have been marking international women 's day with an unprecedented strike targeting gender inequality and sexual discrimination .
unions said 5.3 million women had joined the 24-hour strike , backed by 10 unions and some of spain 's top women politicians .
hundreds of thousands of women joined street protests across spain , shouting : `` if we stop , the world stops . ''
events marking the day have been held in dozens of other nations .

documents.title: disney shareholders vote against boss 's pay
text: shareholders in walt disney have rejected the executive compensation plan for chief executive bob iger and other leaders in a non binding vote .
fifty-two per cent voted against disney 's compensation plan , according to preliminary results announced at the company 's annual general meeting .
44 % percent voted in favour while 4 % abstained .
in december , mr iger 's contract was extended until 2021 when disney announced plans to acquire film and tv businesses from twenty-first century fox in a $ 52.4bn deal .
under the extension , mr iger is eligible for salary and bonuses totaling $ 48.5m when the transaction is completed , according to a regulatory filing .

commenting on the vote , aylwin lewis , chair of the board 's compensation committee , said : `` the board accepts the result of today 's non-binding vote and will take it under advisement for future ceo compensation . ''

documents.title: euro slumps
text: the ecb 's decision today to keep rates on hold - and downgrade its inflation forecast for the eurozone - has hit the euro hard .
the currency is 0.84 % lower against the dollar at $ 1.2311 .
the pound 's also down 0.65 % at $ 1.3806

documents.title: us stocks lose ground
text: wall street is getting edgy ahead of a 3.30pm et ( 8:30 gmt ) announcement from donald trump .
he is set to sign into law tariffs of 25 % on steel and 10 % on aluminum .
however , he has suggested mexico and canada will be exempt as part of nafta talks , and other countries could see relief if they are `` real friends '' of the us in terms of trade .
having started the day strongly , the dow jones index is now down 0.2 % , while the s & p 500 and nasdaq are flat .

documents.title: dutch politicians lambaste ing for boss 's pay
text: dutch bank ing has angered politicians with a proposal to increase the pay of its chief executive ralph hamers by 50 % .
ralph hamers , who has led ing since october 2013 , will receive the extra pay in the form of ing shares worth 50 % of his base salary of 1.75 million euros .
he received a total of almost 2 million euros in 2017 .
finance minister wopke hoekstra said the increase was excessive '' , while members of parliament called for a public hearing to hold ing chairman jeroen van der veer to account
dutch politicians have tried to limit pay for bank executives since the financial crisis , including by limiting performance bonuses to a maximum of 20 % of base salaries .
mr hamers ' pay rise comes in the form of a guaranteed shares reward , independent of the bank 's performance .

documents.title: cptpp to lift 98 % of trade barriers
text: as trade deals go , this is an ambitious treaty - specially at a time when protectionism is on the rise again .
eleven countries agreed to lift 98 % of trade barriers - and will now seek to ratify that deal in their own respective parliaments .
trade ministers here in chile said the trans-pacific trade pact , or tpp , will create more jobs and income for half a billion people through free trade .
but not everyone is on board .
trade unions and opposition parties in virtually all countries say only big corporations will win - and not common workers .
last year the tpp suffered a major setback when president donald trump abandoned talks .
but today in chile the remaining countries said that the door is open for the us , or any other nation in the planet , to join the free trade area .
author: Daniel Gallas
BBC South America business correspondent

documents.title: cptpp trade deal signed by 11 nations
text: eleven asia-pacific countries have just signed the trade pact formerly known as the trans-pacific partnership .
although the us pulled out last year , the deal was salvaged by the remaining members who have signed it at a ceremony in chile .
since then , the agreement has been given the even more unwieldy name of the comprehensive and progressive agreement for trans-pacific partnership ( cptpp ) .
extraneous adjectives aside , its supporters say it 's hugely significant , and could be a model for future trade deals .
read more

documents.title: snap under pressure ?
text: snap had just over 3,000 employees at the end of 2017 , which means the company is cutting roughly 4 % of its total workforce .
while that may seem small , all is clearly not well at the $ 21bn tech firm , which listed on the new york stock exchange last year .

the maker of the popular app , known for its disappearing messages , has been under pressure from investors to reduce costs after revenue fell short of analyst expectations during snap 's first year as a publicly traded company .
its shares are still some way below their ipo value .
the firm has struggled to fend off competition from facebook and remains heavily loss making .

documents.title: snapchat to cut jobs
text: snap , the parent of snapchat , will cut over 120 engineers and reorganise its engineering team , according to a company memo seen by reuters .
the smartphone app known for popularizing disappearing messages will offer a package of benefits to those being laid off , the memo from engineering chief jerry hunter said .

documents.title: trump hangs tough on tariffs
text: donald trump is to press ahead with the imposition of 25 % tariffs on steel imports and 10 % on aluminum , although he said was willing to strike a deal that could exempt canada and mexico .
the president has repeatedly suggested there would be relief from the taxes for countries that `` treat us fairly on trade '' .
at the start of a cabinet meeting he told reporters : `` i 'm sticking with 10 and 25 ( per cent ) initially .
i 'll have a right to go up or down , depending on the country , and i 'll have a right to drop out countries or add countries . ''
he is expected to announce the duties later on thursday .

documents.title: ec sues britain
text: the eu is taking legal action against the uk to recover €2.7bn in lost customs duties after london allegedly ignored a scam by chinese importers .
the european commission said it had decided to send a `` letter of formal notice '' over the case , which was uncovered by brussels ' anti-fraud watchdog last year .

the dow jones index is down 0.2 % at 24,740.06 points .
the nasdaq has pared gains to trade 0.11 % higher at 7,404.50 , while the s & p 500 is down 0.1 % at 2,723.58 .

documents.title: kfc renews contract with bidvest
text: kfc has renewed a partnership with its old supplier bidvest after a chicken shortage forced it to shut hundreds of outlets last month .
the fast food giant ran out of poultry , then gravy , after switching its logistics partner to dhl in a bid to save money .
a kfc spokesman said : our focus remains on ensuring our customers can enjoy our chicken without further disruption .

with that in mind , the decision has been taken in conjunction with qsl and dhl [ which together run a supply chain ] to revert the distribution contract for up to 350 of our restaurants in the north of the uk back to bidvest logistics .
`` we 've been working hard to resolve the present situation with qsl and dhl .
this decision will ease pressure at dhl 's rugby depot , to help get our restaurants back to normal as quickly as possible . ''
around 97 % of kfc 's 900 restaurants are now open for business , although the firm is still offering `` limited menus '' at some outlets .

documents.title: ftse 100 closes higher
text: the london market has closed up 0.6 % at 7,203.24 points , following other european markets higher .
germany 's dax and france 's cac 40 gained 1 % and 1.5 % respectively , after the european central bank kept eurozone interest rates on hold .
david madden , an analyst at cmc markets , said : `` mario draghi , the head of the ecb , stated that underlying inflation is subdued and that 'victory ' ca n't be declared yet .
`` the implication is the region still has some way to go in order to stimulate demand .
the dovish tone of the press conference encouraged buying of stocks , and the slide in the euro added to the bullish sentiment . ''

documents.title: mayfield not worried about john lewis
text: john lewis chairman sir charlie mayfield says he is not worried about the state of the retailer after it reported a 20 % fall in profits today .
he told radio 5 live the dip was largely due to `` squeezed margins '' at waitrose because of the weaker pound , which meant `` cost prices went up faster than the selling prices '' .
however , he would n't rule out further closures at waitrose after six stores shut last year .
no one can ever rule out store closures but the point i would really emphasise is we have a strong position when it comes to our shops .
it 's helped us historically and it 'll help us in the future . ''
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: 'ty dovish ' ecb fails to impress euro
text: having briefly climbed after the ecb 's rate announcement earlier , the euro is now down 0.6 % against the dollar .

connor campbell , an analyst at spreadex , says that despite a `` notable tweak '' to the central bank 's message - with it ditching any mention of increasing its bond-buying programme - the ecb 's overall stance was ty dovish .
this , coupled with a downward revision to the eurozone 's 2019 's inflation forecasts , has spooked currency investors .
conversely , though , it boosted stocks .
`` the lack of properly hawkish sentiment helped the eurozone indices more than it hurt the euro .
[ germany 's ] dax rose 0.9 % , soaring back across 12,350 in the process , while [ france 's ] cac managed an impressive 1.3 % increase , taking the french bourse to a one week peak . ''

documents.title: for chief executives 'luck better than talent '
text: `` being a talented executive is good , but being lucky is even better , '' says barry ritholtz , a money manager , and sharp observer of the us corporate scene .
in this piece for bloomberg he analyses why executive pay in the us has gone haywire .
he points out that us bosses are not paid for for how well their companies perform , but how the stock market does , because so much of their pay is in share awards .
`` all but the most incompetent executives who have served as ceos since mid-2009 have seen their company share prices soar , '' he writes .
`` why are executives reaping such large rewards for a stock-market recovery that is n't of their making ? ''
he asks .

documents.title: tesco bank cancels cards
text: tesco bank has cancelled some of its customers ' credit cards after concerns that a number of accounts may have been compromised .
customers may have to wait up to a week before replacement cards are issued .
the bank said that only a tiny number of its three million credit card users would be affected , and apologised for the inconvenience .
in 2016 , tesco bank suffered a large-scale attack on some of its customers ' current accounts .
20,000 people had to be refunded .

documents.title: bmw profits soar
text: profits jumped 26 % at bmw in 2017 thanks to strong demand for electric cars and a boost from donald trump 's tax reforms .
the german luxury car maker earned a record 8.7 billion euros ( $ 10.7 billion ) , as deliveries of electrified cars soared by 65.6 % to 103,080 units .
corporate tax cuts in the us also contributed 977 million euros to the bottom line .
the group , which also owns the mini and rolls-royce brands , said total sales rose 4.8 % to 98.6 billion euros .

documents.title: draghi bashes trump steel tariffs
text: ecb chief mario draghi has spoken out strongly ( well , strongly for him ) against plans by donald trump to put up tariffs against steel and aluminium imports to the us .

`` there is a certain worry or concern about the state of international relations , because if you put tariffs against your allies , one wonders who the enemies are , '' mr draghi said , warning that `` unilateral decisions are dangerous '' .

documents.title: costless nationalisation is 'fake news '
text: the head of the british chambers of commerce has taken a swing at labour 's plans for taking major infrastructure back into government ownership .
adam marshall said at the business body 's annual conference that the idea of costless nationalisation is quite simply fake news '' .

labour , under jeremy corbyn and john mcdonnell , have called for railways , water and major public-private partnerships to be nationalised , and said it can be done without major costs to the taxpayer .
but mr marshall said mass nationalisation would roll back the merits of privatisation , and that it is up to business to face down this superficially persuasive argument .
author: Dan Macadam
BBC business reporter

documents.title: ecb taps brakes on bond buying
text: the ecb has abandoned a commitment to increase bond-buying if needed - which has been in every statement since december 2016 .

capital economics analyst jennifer mckeown says `` the change is arguably the ecb 's first cautious step along a path of gradual policy normalisation '' away from €30bn a month of bond-buying and historic low interest rates .
bond purchases at that pace will continue until september at least , while the ecb also left key interest rates unchanged .

documents.title: draghi warns on protectionism
text: european central bank president mario draghi is giving a press conference following the bank 's decision to keep eurozone rates on hold .
he warned that `` rising protectionism '' could harm growth in the eurozone after president trump sparked fears of a global trade war
`` downside risks relate primarily to global factors including rising protectionism and developments in foreign exchange and other financial markets , '' mr draghi said .

documents.title: mcdonnell : hammond wrong to favour financial services
text: the uk should not favour financial services over other sectors of the economy as it negotiates its future trading relationship with the european union after brexit , shadow chancellor john mcdonnell told the british chambers of commerce conference .
he said philip hammond was wrong to suggest that parts of the ttip trade agreement could be a model for future ties between britain and the eu , as it favoured lawyers and big corporations .
`` it is now clear that the government 's priorities are to win a deal for financial services first and then worry about the rest of the economy later , '' he said .

`` there is no other reason to raise a specific deal for financial services , even if it is as bad and fantastical as proposed , while just last week refusing to negotiate a new customs union that would protect our manufacturing trade , '' he added .
`` we need a government that pays a little less time to the rentiers and speculators and more time for those who work in and out of businesses and run companies . ''

documents.title: sun setting on maplin
text: it 's not looking good for maplin .
pwc , the joint administrators of the electronics chain , has made 63 staff redundant at its head offices in london and rotherham .
more worryingly , they say `` it has not been possible to secure a buyer for the business '' .
the company is continuing to trade but due to a lack of interest we may be required to initiate a controlled closure programme .
we still believe there is strong value in the company and we remain focused on doing all we can to preserve the business while we continue trying to achieve a sale . ''

documents.title: euro perks-up after ecb announcement
text: the euro perked-up following the interest rate announcement from the european central bank .
it had been trading as low as $ 1.2369 against the dollar , but has risen by more than half a cent to $ 1.2423
according to analysts it is significant that the ecb dropped its promise to increase purchases of government debt , if necessary to boost the economy .
that 's seen as a small effort to wind back stimulus measures , which has given the euro some support .
the key is that the ecb has dropped the language about doing more if the economic and financial conditions worsen .
it ' s a tacit acknowledgement that the economic outlook in europe is rosier than it was , '' said james athey from aberdeen standard investments .

documents.title: ecb keeps rates on hold
text: as expected the european central bank has kept interest rates at record lows .

documents.title: sterling slips
text: sterling has eased lower against the dollar .
the pound is being depressed by a disagreement over the eu 's draft guidelines for a trade deal with the uk .

the pound is down about 0.3 % to $ 1.3863 and is broadly flat on the euro .

documents.title: apple and amazon eye us health business
text: as we mentioned earlier us healthcare companies have been scrambling to do deals .
experts say that it is partly a defensive move , as big technology companies including amazon and apple have been eyeing their industry .
in january amazon announced a partnership with the bank jp morgan and investment giant berkshire hathaway to provide healthcare services for their employees .
but analysts think it might be the first step for amazon into the pharmacy business or healthcare administration .
and in february apple announced that it was launching medical clinics for its own employees , but there 's speculation that it may be used as test bed for new devices and services .

documents.title: breakingcigna to buy express scripts for $ 67bn

health insurer cigna is buying express scripts in a deal valued at $ 67bn .
it 's part of a round of deals among companies in the health business .
in december , pharmacy chain cvs health announced the purchase of insurer aetna in a deal worth $ 68bn .
and in february the pharmacy chain rite aid was bought by the grocer albertsons .

documents.title: brexit payments to be laid out : ft

the government has agreed to payments of between £ 35bn and £ 39bn .

documents.title: price cuts hit waitrose
text: waitrose posted gross sales of £ 6.75bn last year , up 1.8 % , while like-for-like sales ( excluding fuel ) were 0.9 % higher - considerably better than the 0.2 % fall for 2016 .
like-for-like sales growth accelerated in the second half , increasing from 0.7 % to 1.1 % after prices were cut on hundreds of essential waitrose products .
operating profit before exceptional items fell almost a third to £ 172m primarily due to lower margins as the chain absorbed some cost price inflation .

documents.title: 'subdued ' demand
text: john lewis chairman sir charlie mayfield says consumer demand was subdued and the business has made significant changes to operations that affected many partners .

we said in january 2017 that we were preparing for tougher trading conditions with weakness in sterling feeding through into cost prices , putting pressure on margin , and much higher exceptional costs as a result of an acceleration of planned changes .

this was why we chose to reduce the proportion of profits paid as partnership bonus last year so as to absorb these impacts while continuing to invest in the future and in strengthening our balance sheet . ''

documents.title: 'not a great number ' from waitrose
text: retail analyst steve dresser is not impressed by the numbers from waitrose .
he tweets :
waitrose like for likes +0.9 % overall , 0.7 % in h1 before an 'acceleration ' in h2 to 1.1 % .
given backdrop of market inflation it 's not a great number .
not great reading for waitrose , heading in to turnaround at a difficult time economically .
discounters running amok on premium particularly means there wo n't be that 'bounce ' that they had in the last slowdown
they just changed their loyalty card scheme .
not to mention morale of staff since they restructured teams last year it all counts .
another company enters the running for the race to the bottom .

documents.title: breakingprofits slide at john lewis ; staff bonus falls
text: john lewis has reported a pre-tax profit of £ 289.2m for last year .
that 's down 22 % on last year .
like-for-like sales at the john lewis department stores were up 0.4 % .
at waitrose like-for-like sales rose 0.9 % - a return to growth .
john lewis staff face the fifth year in a row of falling bonus .
this year it will be 5 % of salary .

documents.title: shares in alfa financial plunge
text: shares in alfa financial software have plunged 20 % this morning , making it the biggest loser among ftse 250 firms today .
you may not have heard of it , but it provides software for finance companies .
it reported a doubling of profit last year to £ 33.8m .
sales rose 20 % to £ 87.8m .
however , due to the weakening dollar it expects sales growth to slow this year to the low double-digits .

documents.title: vw to pay bigger bonuses
text: it '' s a good day for volkswagen workers - the car company 's bumper profits has prompted a 40 % rise in their annual bonuses to €4,100 , according to a document seen by reuters ahead of the announcement later today .
about 120,000 vw workers in germany will get the higher payment after group profit nearly doubled last year to €13.8bn followijg a 6 % rise in sales .

`` employees had a major share [ in the fact ] that the vw brand , despite all adversities , is in a much better position today , '' vw chief executive herbert diess ( is quoted as saying in the newsletter .

documents.title: 'more agile working needed in legal sector '
text: on international women 's day funke abimbola ( tells today that after returning to her city law firm following a year 's maternity leave she was classified as a `` woman returner '' .
that raised `` all sorts of issues about how i could work '' and how she could fit in with an `` inherently misogynist setup '' and its culture of long hours .
ms abimbola decided to move out of central london to regional practice where she could work full-time but keep more regular hours .
`` since then firms are doing much more to accommodate these sorts of requests .
i see a lot more 'agile working ' and being encouraged a lot more in solicitors ' firms , '' she says .

however , there remains a need for more visible role models , which ms abimbola says is one aim of the first 100 years - a history project , supported by the law society and the bar council , that charts the journey of women in the law in the uk since 1919 .
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: asian markets rebound as trade fears subside
text: asian shares found relief on thursday after us president donald trump signalled there might some exemptions to his proposed tariffs on steel and aluminium .
the nikkei closed 0.54 % higher at 21368.07 , while the kospi and emerging market indexes also posted gains .
hong kong 's hang seng climbed 1.52 % to close at 30654.52 , while the mainland indexes also gained .
australia 's asx 200 edged 0.69 % higher to 5,942.90 .

documents.title: markets : countrywide plunges , g4s down

among bigger firms , shares in outsourcing firm g4s are down 2.4 % after it reported annual sales that were slightly less than had been expected .
overall , there 's been no big move for the ftse 100 in early trading .

documents.title: iod chair steps aside : report
text: lady judge is temporarily stepping aside as chair of the institute of directors following an investigation into her conduct with staff , the times reports .
the iod will meet on thursday afternoon to discuss the outcome of an investigation into the allegations .
a spokesman for the institute of directors said : our hr department was made aware of a number of allegations from staff members concerning the conduct of non-executive members of our board . ''
an investigation into the allegations has been carried out by law firm hill dickinson .
the iod could not confirm to the bbc whether lady judge was still in her role .

documents.title: countrywide investors being 'sorely tested
text: troubled estate agency countrywide says it will see little improvement in trading in the short term .
britain 's biggest chain of estate agents has posted bottom-line losses of £ 208.1m for 2017 , against profits of £ 17.5m the year before , and says a return to the black `` will take time '' .
the firm 's chief executive left last month after a profit warning and the announcement of a restructuring of the business , whose brands include hamptons and gascoigne-pees .
`` fundamentally , countrywide has a unique market position given its breadth within the property services industry , '' says executive chairman peter long .
`` we believe these business units are fixable this will take time but ultimately there will be much upside for our group and our shareholders , whose patience has been sorely tested recently .

documents.title: g4s higher
text: g4s , the world 's largest security group , has had a good 2017 , with revenue up 3.2 % to £ 7.43bn - although that was short of the £ 7.55bn expected by analysts .
pre-tax profits for the outsourcer were £ 75m higher at £ 386m .
chief executive ashley almanza said the outlook for g4s was positive .

`` our strong market positions , commercial discipline , growing technology-related revenues , positive cash generation and on-going productivity programmes provide substantial confidence that the group is well positioned to deliver a strong performance over the next three years . ''

documents.title: domino 's aims high
text: domino 's had 1,045 stores in the uk as of 31 december , with another 147 in other markets .
the pizza delivery firm says a new supply chain centre in warrington will help meet its target of reaching at least 1,600 sites .

`` the market continues to be competitive but the strength of our brand and scale , combined with the expertise of our franchisees , are important competitive advantages in delivering quality , convenience and value to customers , '' domino 's says .

documents.title: aviva reports strong year
text: insurance giant aviva has reported a 2 % rise in operating profit for last year to £ 3.1bn .
`` our largest market , the uk , has gone from strength to strength , growing sales , market share and profit .
for aviva , the uk is a dependable and growing business , '' said mark wilson , aviva chief executive .
this year the company expects to reduce its debt by £ 900m , return £ 500m to shareholder and have £ 600m available to buy other businesses .

documents.title: domino 's sales growth slows
text: domino 's broke through the £ 1bn barrier for the first time in 2017 last year , helped by 95 new store openings - although the 4.8 % rise in like-for-like sales was less than half the rate of 2016 .
underlying pre-tax profit was up 10.2 % to £ 96.2m .
chief executive david wild said it was `` a year of significant progress for domino 's , despite the weaker consumer demand and cost inflation affecting the sector '' .

documents.title: french firms face gender pay gap fines
text: french companies caught discriminating against women over pay will be given three years to close the gap or face fines under new labour proposals .
if the proposals are passed by parliament , they will come into effect by 2020 .
software would be installed on company payroll systems to monitor unjustified pay gaps .
men are still paid on average 9 % more than women in france despite equal pay laws going back 45 years .
more here .

documents.title: business pages : foxhunting , lloyds and syria
text: let 's take a look at some of the business stories in the newspapers .
according to the telegraph tesco has been `` hounded '' into removing a foxhunting fancy dress costume from its children 's range , after hunt saboteurs complained .
the times reports that lloyds tsb agreed to move £ 800,000 in fees due to be paid to accountants pwc from its 2008 accounts , to avoid breaching its own limit on how much pwc could be paid .
and the financial times takes an in-depth look at a huge controversy in france surrounding cement-making giant lafargeholcim .
french authorities are investigating payments made by the company to keep its plant in syria open , while the country was descending into civil war .

documents.title: why we need a female warren buffett
text: earlier this year maike currie of fidelity international ( was sent a title called harriman 's new book of investing rules : the dos and don'ts of the world 's best investors by the financial publisher harriman house .

reviewing the book for the financial times she pointed out that it featured contributions from 67 men ( one of whom is jacob rees-mogg ) - and just one woman ( kathleen brooks from city index , as it happens ) .
ms currie tells today there are some very good female fund managers , but as long as they are ignored the perception will be is that `` investment is for blokes '' .
she asks why we do n't have a `` female version of warren buffett '' - and points out that while women are very good with money many tend to shy away from investment .
and as ms currie pointed out in her review : `` it would be great if there was a single female investor or fund manager that was a household name like benjamin graham , john bogle or john templeton .
but there is n't yet
author: Today Programme
BBC Radio 4

documents.title: china dominates self-made female billionaire rich list
text: chinese publisher hurun has put out its list of the world 's richest self-made women billionaires .
and once again china is dominant with 28 of the top 50 , five of the top 10 and four of the top five all form the asian superpower .
zhou qunfei , who founded a firm that makes the glass used to cover laptops and smartphones , was the world 's richest self-made woman , with $ 9.8bn ( £ 7.1bn ) .
ms zhou , who came from a poor rural background , also featured on the forbes billionaires list released earlier this week .
forbes ranked her as the world 's 16th richest woman overall , with all of those above her appearing to have inherited or married into their wealth .
author: Simon Atkinson
Asia Business Reporter

documents.title: 'massive ' disparity in male and female bonuses
text: it is international women 's day and wake up to money talks to gina miller , known for her campaign to get a parliamentary vote on brexit .
she is also co- founder of investment firm scm .
her company is 50 % staffed by women and they are all paid the same .
while financial firms might give equal base salaries , bonuses are far from equal she says .
there is a `` massive '' disparity between the bonuses given to men and women at city firms and there is no transparency about that , she points out .
she also says that ethnic diversity has deteriorated in the financial services industry .
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: 'inevitable ' that shops will close on the high street
text: yesterday we learnt that another high street retailer has run into trouble , when new look announced the closure of 60 stores .
`` it is inevitable that there will be less retail on the high street , '' says mark williams who was chairman of the last government task force to look at town centres .
town centres need `` comprehensive redevelopment '' he told wake up to money .
retail space needs to be converted to housing and office space for entrepreneurs .
many towns are doing this he says .
for example , basildon in essex has bought a college into the town centre , plus a cinema and more restaurants and bars .
business rates are a `` toxic tax '' which needs a `` wholesale review '' , mr williams says .
but it 's a tricky issue , he points out , as the government raises £ 29bn a year from it .
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: 'government needs to do more than negotiate brexit '
text: `` government can do more than one thing at once , '' adam marshall , the director general of the british chambers of commerce ( bcc ) tells wake up to money .
his organisation is worried that brexit is taking up too much of the government 's time and attention .

`` the best possible brexit deal will not matter to the uk 's competitiveness if the roads remain potholed and congested , if you ca n't get mobile phone coverage around the uk , if business broadband is poor and companies ca n't get the people they need because the training system is n't working to deliver for them . ''
he will be speaking at the bcc conference in london later .
author: BBC Radio 5 live

documents.title: good morning !
text: welcome to thursday 's business live page .
is brexit taking up too much of the government 's bandwidth ?
the british chambers of commerce thinks so and wants other issues tackled .
it is international women 's day and we 'll be hearing from top female executives about how to better attract and reward female staff .
and one of the giants in british retail , john lewis , reports results later .
